items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high tides coinciding with high river levels.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible between 10:00 today, 03/01/25, and 05:00 tomorrow, 04/01/25.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
We expect river levels to peak on the high tide at 11:30, and at 23:30 today, 03/01/25, at Torksey.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 17:00 this evening, 03/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are within banks, but remain high, on the River Windrush, particularly in the Bourton on the Water and Newbridge areas. Today is forecast to be mainly dry. Widespread rain with a chance of snow is forecast from Saturday night into Sunday. We expect  river levels to remain high over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
Flooding of low-lying land by the River Yeo is currently possible at and downstream of Sherborne, but flooding of buildings is not expected.
Little or no rainfall is expected until the weekend and flooding is not expected to increase.
We have checked rivers for blockages and are closely monitoring the situation.
Please take care and avoid using low lying roads and footpaths in the vicinity.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the afternoon and no further flooding is expected. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

River levels are still rising at the Tern-Walcot River gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.    

No further significant rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   

This message will be updated by 10:00am on 03/01/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout today and no further flooding is expected.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers in Hellingly and Alfriston are all now falling following Wednesday's rain. Only isolated showers are predicted Thursday through to Saturday. River levels will continue to fall. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads and gardens are expected to ease throughout Thursday in both Hellingly and Alfriston. On Sunday 05/01/2025, another 20-40mm of rain is forecast, which could increase flood risk again. Plan to avoid driving routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. River levels should return to near normal levels from Friday 03/01/2025. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message if flooding of properties is possible.

River levels are rising at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads on both sides of the river from Tewkesbury to Quedgeley, Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill.  

Predicted peaks:- Mythe 2.5 to 3m on Saturday evening, 04/01/25, Haw Bridge 3.5 to 4m on Saturday evening, Sandhurst 2.5 to 3m Saturday evening, Gloucester 2.5 to 3m on Saturday evening.  

Further rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services and or Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 04/01/25, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is now falling following Wednesday's rain. Only isolated showers are predicted for the rest of Thursday 02/01/2025 through to Saturday 04/01/2025. River levels will continue to fall. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads and gardens around Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge, Anchor Inn and Barcombe Mills are expected to ease. On Sunday 05/01/2025, another 20-40mm of rain is forecast, which could increase flood risk again. Plan to avoid driving routes susceptible to flooding such as Barcombe Mills Road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will reissue this message if flooding of properties is possible.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves on Friday morning, 03/01/2025, may lead to flooding. 

Areas most at risk include beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
 
Astronomical tides peak on Friday afternoon and this alert may remain valid until then. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences. 

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

Highest tide level is expected to be at beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads at 5:30 AM on 03/01/2025. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. 

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 10am Thursday 2nd January, and over the next 24 hours. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides and tidal surge at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. The current series of high spring tides have peaked, although a tidal surge is restricting the river flows draining out to sea at low tide as normal. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am Friday 3rd January.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 10am Thursday 2nd January, and over the next 24 hours. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides and tidal surge at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. The current series of high spring tides have peaked, although a tidal surge is restricting the river flows draining out to sea at low tide as normal. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am Friday 3rd January.

River levels are now steadily falling, but still remain quite high in some locations. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.93mAOD at 17:00 on 03/01/2025.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels peak today. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 121 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

Thursday's afternoon tide at 12:45 on 02/01/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days, and accompanied by light Northerly Force 4 winds. The weather still increases tide table values by 0.12 m. The total forecast tide is 5.79 metres Chart Datum (2.74 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Over the weekend, strong winds, large waves and minor flood impacts are forecast to return. We continue to monitor the forecast. It is possible will reissue this Flood Alert on Saturday 04/01/2025.

River levels remain high at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. 

Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood.  

Predicted peaks:-  

Llanymynech peaked at 4.68m on Wednesday afternoon;  

Cae Howel 4.7m to 5.2m Thursday afternoon, 02/01/25. 

Flood water could be deep and fast flowing and therefore pose a risk to life.  

No further significant rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on 03/01/25, or as the situation changes.

Weather conditions are expected to improve this afternoon and no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

River levels have fallen in the Upper River Aire Catchment throughout the night and are now below levels of concern. This Flood Alert is therefore no longer in force.
No further significant rainfall is forecast today or tomorrow and river levels are expected to continue to fall throughout this period.
We will continue to closely monitor the forecast as rivers will be responsive to any further rainfall. A period of rain and snow is forecast late on Saturday 04 January into Sunday 05 January 2025. We will reissue this alert if necessary.
Please be aware that standing water may still remain on low-lying land, roads and in adjacent washlands.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  Further snow and rainfall is forecast over the weekend.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land.  Further snow and rainfall is forecast over the weekend.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester
items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Dee.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Dee, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.
Townfield Lane is expected to be cut off.
We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 04/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Bewdley river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. 

We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke and Upton upon Severn. Install Property level protection if required.  

Predicted peaks:- Bewdley 3.5 to 3.6m on Saturday morning, 04/01/25, Worcester 3 to 3.4 on Saturday evening, Diglis 2.5 to 3m on Saturday evening, Kempsey Yacht Club 4.6 to 5.1m on Saturday evening, Saxons Lode 3.5 to 4m on Saturday evening.  

Further rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and liaising with emergency services and Local Authorities. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday, 04/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Levels remain high on the Lower River Ure. River Levels have peaked and are now falling but flooding remains possible today, Friday 03/01/2025. Areas most at risk include low-lying land including agricultural land and local roads in the areas around Masham, Boroughbridge, Aldborough and Aldwark Bridge. Levels are expected to continue to fall, and no further significant rainfall is forecast today.

Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. 

This message will be updated by 7pm on Friday 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain elevated in the Tidal River Aire Catchment as water from rainfall in the upper Aire and Calder catchments works its way down the River Aire.
River levels have peaked at Carlton Bridge but will remain high over the coming days. Some of the surrounding washlands continue to fill.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Aire, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the River Aire from Temple Hirst to Airmyn.
We do not currently expect to issue any flood warnings but will do so if required.
We will continue to closely monitor the forecast as rivers will be responsive to any further rainfall. A period of rain and snow is forecast late on Saturday 04 January into Sunday 05 January 2025.
This message will be updated by 8:00 PM on Friday 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are falling at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday on 04/01/25.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 18:00 this evening, 03/01/25, or as the situation changes.

No further significant rainfall is expected tonight. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Warnings if necessary. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 09:00 on Friday 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley.  

Crew Green peaked at 6.24m on Thursday morning, 02/01/25. 

No further significant rainfall is expected over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid roads that may be flooded.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast this afternoon at 3:00 PM on 03/01/2025.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to a large tidal surge coinciding with high spring tides.
Areas most at risk include low lying land, promenades and coastal footpaths.
Flooding is possible at low lying land, promenades and coastal footpaths between 1:00 PM and 5:00 PM this afternoon on 03/01/2025.
No property flooding is expected.
High spring tides are expected to reduce over the coming days. However, we will issue further messages if required.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
For those that need it, the total peak water level at Sheerness is forecasted to be 3.49m AOD.
This message will be updated by 7:00 PM tonight on 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: Levels on the River Ouse in York remain high following recent heavy rainfall. Levels have peaked and are beginning to slowly fall today, Friday 03/01/2025. Flooding is expected to affect locations near the River Ouse, particularly around properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. We are closely monitoring the situation and are operating the Foss Barrier. Activate any property flood protection products you may have. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 4pm on Friday 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels on the Lower River Don have been falling through today, Thursday 2nd January and will continue to fall overnight and through Friday. The main period of flood risk has now passed, subsequently this Flood Alert is no longer in force.
Standing water may continue to affect low lying land and minor roads, therefore remain vigilant and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
Rivers will be responsive to any further rainfall. A period of rain and snow is forecast late on Saturday 04 January into Sunday 05 January. We will continue to closely monitor the forecast and will re-issue this Flood Alert if necessary.

River levels remain high, but steady at the Yoxall river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent.   
Drier conditions are forecast today Thursday 02/01/25 and tomorrow Friday 03/01/25. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Friday 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast for next 48 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have slowly started to recede. Levels are very reactive to further rainfall. There is rain forecast for 1st Jan 2025.

After New Year's Day the forecast is for high pressure to build over the next 3-5 days which should see groundwater levels continue to fall.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 7/1/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message:
River levels remain high in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include the River Foulness and its tributaries, particularly around Welham Bridge. No further significant rainfall is expected today, Friday 03/01/2025, however levels are expected to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. 

This message will be updated by 7pm on Friday, 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are slowly rising at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. However, the rate of rise has slowed as a result of recent more settled weather. 

Groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week. We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 07/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently slowly falling at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley as a result of recent settled weather. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the coming weeks if levels begin rising again.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, and levels may rise again following prolonged rainfall. Low-lying land, roads and basements will therefore to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 07/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and remain relatively stable after a week of dry weather. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, the level is very close to causing cellar flooding impacts to a small number of properties. It is also very close to reducing the ability of septic tanks in Old Alresford to operate effectively. Tomorrow (01/01/2025), unsettled weather is forecast to move over Hampshire bringing between 10 and 20mm of rain. From Thursday (02/01/2025) to Saturday (04/01/2025), the weather is expected to be dry. If the heaviest rain in the forecast affects the area, then it is possible that groundwater levels will rise high enough for cellar flooding and septic tank impacts to occur. We continue to monitor the forecast. We advise residents to remain prepared for flooding impacts this winter. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 07/01/2025.

Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday the 8th of January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. This rise is from levels which were already high from the previous Winter. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday the 8th of January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton as a result of recent rainfall. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue slowly rising over the next few weeks and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 07/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

Thursday's afternoon tide at 12:30 on 02/01/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days, and accompanied by light Northerly Force 4 winds. The weather still increases tide table values by 0.14 m. The total forecast tide is 6.62 metres Chart Datum (3.1 mAOD) at Newhaven. Over the weekend, strong winds and large waves are forecast to return, but with tides relatively low no more than minimal flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold and subsequently this Flood Warning is no longer in force. 

No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days and river levels are expected to continue to fall throughout the rest of today and into tomorrow, Friday 03 January 2025.

A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area and flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible, therefore please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local watercourses. We are closely monitoring the situation and will re-issue this Flood Warning if necessary.

items.description: River Aire at Allerton Ings, Barnsdale Road and Properties
items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold and subsequently this Flood Warning is no longer in force. Levels in Allerton Ings continue to fall and Barnsdale Road is expected to reopen today as levels recede.
No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days. River and washland levels are expected to continue to fall throughout this period.
We will continue to closely monitor the forecast as rivers will be responsive to any further rainfall. A period of rain and snow is forecast late on Saturday 04 January into Sunday 05 January 2025. We will reissue this Flood Warning if necessary.
Please be aware that standing water will remain on low-lying land, roads and in adjacent washlands over the coming days. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water.

items.description: River Aire at Snaygill Industrial Estate and Cononley Business Park
items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold, subsequently this Flood Warning is no longer in force.
No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next couple of days and river levels are expected to continue to fall throughout this evening and overnight into tomorrow, Friday 03 January.
Rivers will be responsive to any further rainfall. A period of rain and snow is forecast late on Saturday 04 January into Sunday 05 January. We will continue to closely monitor the forecast and will re-issue this Flood Warning if necessary.
A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area and flooding of roads and low-lying land is still possible, therefore please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near local watercourses.

Thursday's afternoon tide at 12:30 on 02/01/2025 is forecast to be lower than recent days, and accompanied by light Northerly Force 4 winds. The weather still increases tide table values by 0.14 m. The total forecast tide is 6.62 metres Chart Datum (3.1 mAOD) at Newhaven. Over the weekend, strong winds and large waves are forecast to return, but with tides relatively low no more than minimal flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re issue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

This warning has been removed due to river levels falling back below levels of concern. We continue to closely monitor the forecast and will reissue this warning if necessary. A flood alert remains in force for the wider area.

This warning has been removed due to river levels falling back below levels of concern. We continue to closely monitor the forecast and will reissue this warning if necessary. A flood alert remains in force for the wider area.

items.description: River Ure at Aldwark Bridge to Cuddy Shaw Plantation
items.message: This warning has been removed due to river levels falling back below levels of concern. We continue to closely monitor the forecast and will reissue this warning if necessary. A flood alert remains in force for the wider area.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Selby to Faxfleet

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: River levels are high on the Tidal River Ouse as a result of a combination of high tides and recent rainfall. Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river from the A63 near Selby to the Yokefleet, Blacktoft and Faxfleet areas. We have closed locks and flood gates in the area. We expect levels to continue to fall slowly with the tides over the next few days. We continue to monitor levels closely. People in these areas should consider taking action now. We urge people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 21:00 on Friday 03/01/2025, or as the situation changes.
